title: The Effects of Pensions and Retirement Policies on Retirement in Higher Education
author: Alan L. Gustman, Thomas L. Steinmeier
context: This paper studies retirement decisions of tenured male arts-and-sciences faculty at 26 high-quality private U.S. colleges (COFHE) using employment observed as of December 31, 1975 and retirements during 1973–78, with pension plan details reported in 1979 (and 1989 for simulations). Institutional variation includes mandatory retirement ages (65–70), normal and early-retirement eligibility, pension accruals and early-retirement supplements, and Social Security rules. The authors estimate a structural life-cycle retirement model and use Monte Carlo simulations to predict effects of raising/eliminating mandatory retirement and offering early-retirement incentives.

Institutional variation includes mandatory retirement ages (65–70), normal and early-retirement eligibility, pension accruals and early-retirement supplements, and Social Security rules. title: Is Inequality Harmful for Growth? Theory and Evidence
author: Torsten Persson, Guido Tabellini
context: Combining a politico‑economic growth model with empirical tests, the paper examines whether initial income inequality reduces subsequent per‑capita GDP growth. It uses two complementary data sets: a historical panel of nine now‑developed countries divided into 20‑year episodes covering primarily 1830–1970, and a post‑war cross‑section of about 67 countries over 1960–85. Units are country (or country‑period) observations; key covariates are pre‑period inequality (top‑20% share or top20/bottom40 ratio), schooling, franchise restrictions, and initial GDP per capita, exploiting cross‑country and over‑time variation in institutions and redistribution.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; IV

title: Growth in Cities
author: Edward L. Glaeser, Hedi D. Kallal, Jose A. Scheinkman, Andrei Shleifer
context: Using County Business Patterns data for 170 U.S. SMAs, the paper analyzes the top six 2‑digit industries in each city over 1956–1987. The wage-growth regressions (dependent variable: industry wage growth over 1956–1987) are estimated on the subset of 834 city‑industry observations with exact payroll data. The treatment is local competition measured as firms per worker relative to the national industry average. Regressions include controls for 1956 log employment and log wage in the city‑industry, a southern‑city dummy, and national industry employment change.

title: Growth in Cities
author: Edward L. Glaeser, Hedi D. Kallal, Jose A. Scheinkman, Andrei Shleifer
context: Using County Business Patterns employment, payroll, and establishment data for 170 U.S. Standard Metropolitan Areas, the paper examines growth of the top six 2‑digit industries in each city between 1956 and 1987 (≈1,016 city‑industry observations). title: Short and Long Run Externalities
author: Eric J. Bartelsman, Ricardo J. Caballero, Richard K. Lyons
context: Using U.S. manufacturing data for 450 four-digit industries from 1958–1986 (with a 1977 input–output matrix to construct interindustry weights), the paper analyzes how external economies transmit through customer (output-weighted) and supplier (input-weighted) linkages. Units are four-digit manufacturing industries; the study distinguishes short-run (fluctuation-oriented) effects from longer-run (growth-oriented) effects and conducts robustness checks for capacity utilization and alternative activity measures (value added vs. gross production). Identification exploits variation across industries and over time in the postwar U.S. manufacturing sector.

treatment: Allocation of labor across industries and occupations

title: Anatomy of Financial Distress: An Examination of Junk-Bond Issuers
author: Paul Asquith, Robert Gertner, David Scharfstein
treatment: Higher industry leverage / lower industry Tobin's q
context: This analysis uses the sample of 102 U.S. publicly traded firms that issued high‑yield bonds in the 1970s–1980s and experienced financial distress, focusing on actions around the onset of distress (t‑1 to t+1). title: Sectoral Shifts and Unemployment in Interwar Britain
author: S. Lael Brainard
treatment: Cross-section variation in industry excess returns
context: This paper examines causes of persistent high unemployment in interwar Britain (1921–1938), using annual industry-level stock returns and employment data for 103 firms across 11 industries to assess sectoral reallocation shocks' impact on aggregate unemployment. Units include industries (and firm stock indices) and the aggregate unemployment rate. The institutional setting includes the 1925 return to sterling parity and the 1931 abandonment of the gold standard, large export contractions during the Great Depression, and modest aggregate growth; the analysis controls for monetary, fiscal, and benefit-to-wage changes to isolate sectoral shocks.

title: State Infrastructure and Productive Performance
author: Catherine J. Morrison, Amy Ellen Schwartz
context: This paper studies the effect of public infrastructure (state-level public capital) on manufacturing firms' costs and productivity using annual state-level manufacturing data for the 48 contiguous U.S. states over 1970–1987. title: Geographic Localization of Knowledge Spillovers as Evidenced by Patent  Citations
author: Adam B. Jaffe, Manuel Trajtenberg, Rebecca Henderson
context: This paper uses U.S. patent citation data for cohorts of patents applied in 1975 and 1980, tracking citations through 1989, to assess geographic localization of knowledge spillovers at the country, state, and SMSA levels. The units are patents (originating patents from universities, large R&D corporations, and other corporations) and their citing patents, with inventor addresses used to assign geography. The institutional setting is U.S. patenting and university-versus-corporate invention; the authors construct matched control patents by class/year and estimate regressions to test whether citations are more locally concentrated than technology geography predicts.

title: Detection of Bid Rigging in Procurement Auctions
author: Robert H. Porter, J. Douglas Zona
context: This empirical study analyzes sealed-bid New York State Department of Transportation highway procurement auctions in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, Long Island, using paving contracts from April 1979–March 1985. Units are firm-level bids and auction outcomes (116 paving projects, 575 bids). title: Do Gasoline Prices Respond Asymmetrically to Crude Oil Price Changes?
author: Severin Borenstein, A. Colin Cameron
context: This empirical study examines asymmetric transmission of crude oil price changes to gasoline prices using weekly and semi‑monthly data from January 1986–December 1990. It covers U.S. markets east of the Rocky Mountains (WTI crude, Gulf Coast/New York spot gasoline, city terminal branded/unbranded prices averaged across ~17 cities, and retail unleaded regular self‑service averages from 42 cities). Units are market prices at different stages of the refinery–terminal–retail distribution chain. The paper evaluates inventory‑cost and imperfect‑competition explanations using error‑correction/time‑series analysis.

title: Relative-Price Changes as Aggregate Supply Shocks
author: Laurence Ball, N. Gregory Mankiw
context: This paper analyzes U.S. postwar inflation from 1949–1989 by linking annual cross‑sectional distributions of four‑digit PPI industry price changes to aggregate PPI inflation. Working from a menu‑cost model of nominal rigidity, the authors argue that skewness in relative‑price changes (for example, large oil shocks) shifts the short‑run Phillips curve. Empirically they compute yearly moments (weighted and unweighted) of industry price changes, estimate AR(1) time‑series and Phillips‑curve regressions including detrended unemployment, and examine historical episodes.

title: Measuring the Cyclicality of Real Wages: How Important is Composition Bias
author: Gary Solon, Robert Barsky, Jonathan A. Parker
context: Using U.S. data from roughly 1967–87 (PSID interviews 1968–88 covering calendar years 1967–87) and aggregate BLS/GNP time series, the paper studies individual- and cohort-level real wage responses over the business cycle. Units are workers/household heads (micro panel observations) and aggregate wage series; cycle indicators include the civilian unemployment rate and real GNP growth. The authors investigate how composition shifts in hours worked (more low-skill hours in expansions) bias aggregate measures and compare balanced/unbalanced PSID panel estimates to decompose true real-wage procyclicality.

title: Wages, Profits and Rent-Sharing
author: David G. Blanchflower, Andrew J. Oswald, Peter Sanfey
context: This paper analyzes US manufacturing wage determination using CPS March microdata for roughly 400,000 workers aggregated into 19 industry-by-year cells over 1964–1985. Industry-level profit and unemployment series (profit data available 1958–1985, aggregated to 2-digit SIC) are merged with cell means of individual characteristics to test rent-sharing versus competitive and contract models. Estimations use dynamic panel specifications with year dummies and both fixed- and random-effects to trace contemporaneous and lagged profit effects on mean wages.

title: A Tax-Based Test of the Dividend Signaling Hypothesis
author: B. Douglas Bernheim, Adam Wantz
context: Analyzes U.S. publicly traded firms’ dividend-increase announcements during 1962–1988 (with focused analyses 1978–1988), using daily CRSP returns and Compustat bond ratings. Unit of observation is the firm-announcement; the study exploits temporal variation in dividend taxation (Poterba’s THETA and major U.S. tax reforms around 1981 and 1986) and cross-firm differences in bond ratings as proxies for marginal dividend costs. The main outcome is three-day cumulative abnormal returns around dividend announcement windows to assess how tax and financial conditions affect market responses.

title: Generics and New Goods in Pharmaceutical Price Indexes
author: Zvi Griliches, Iain Cockburn
context: This paper uses monthly IMS America wholesale transaction data on U.S. prescription pharmaceuticals—focusing on cephalexin and cephradine—from the mid-1980s through 1990 (patent expirations in April 1987). It analyzes how patent expiration, FDA therapeutic-equivalence certification, and subsequent generic entry and diffusion across product-presentations affect wholesale prices, market shares, and official CPI/PPI-style price indexes. Units are product-presentations (packages), quantities, and revenues; the institutional setting emphasizes FDA rules, patent timing, and statistical agency index construction.

author: Roland Benabou
context: This triplet comes from a theoretical comparative‑statics analysis of economies with heterogeneous agents interacting via local public goods and economy‑wide linkages. Units are families/communities and aggregate economies in a general (non–country‑specific) setting, with emphasis on long‑run output/productivity under varying local and global complementarities.

title: Tobin's Q, Corporate Diversification and Firm Performance
author: Larry H.P. Lang, Rene M. Stulz
context: This paper studies U.S. publicly traded firms using Compustat segment data over 1978–1990 (focus year 1984), examining how corporate diversification (number of reported segments under SFAS No.14) relates to firm value measured by Tobin’s q (replacement‑cost adjusted). Analyses adjust for industry composition via a “chop‑shop” pure‑play counterfactual and control for size, R&D intensity, and capital‑market access in the U.S. institutional setting.

title: Sticking it Out: Entrepreneurial Survival and Liquidity Constraints
author: Douglas Holtz-Eakin, David Joulfaian, Harvey S. Rosen
context: This empirical study uses U.S. federal tax records to estimate how inheritance-driven increases in personal assets affect the probability that sole proprietors survive and, conditional on survival, their firms' receipts. It matches estate tax returns for decedents who died in 1982–83 to beneficiaries' individual income tax returns in 1981 and 1985, focusing on relatively high-wealth estates (sample oversamples estates above $300,000). The unit of observation is individual beneficiaries (Schedule C filers); inheritances are treated as plausibly exogenous liquidity shocks within the U.S. tax/inheritance institutional setting.

author: Martin Feldstein
context: This paper uses a U.S. panel of matched individual income tax returns to estimate how the 1986 Tax Reform Act's reductions in marginal income tax rates affected taxable income. title: Factor Hoarding and the Propagation of Business Cycles Shocks
author: Craig Burnside, Martin Eichenbaum
outcome: Positive serial correlation of output growth
context: This paper studies the U.S. aggregate economy (quarterly, 1955:Q3–1984:Q1), using per-capita macro series (output, consumption, investment, hours) to estimate an equilibrium business-cycle model with variable capital utilization and labor effort. Units are the aggregate economy/representative agents and firms; shocks include technology and government-consumption innovations. The authors apply structural GMM estimation, VAR analysis, HP filtering and model simulations to quantify how factor hoarding (variable utilization and effort) amplifies and propagates shocks in postwar U.S. business cycles.

title: The Welfare State and Competitiveness
author: Alberto Alesina, Roberto Perotti
context: Combines a theoretical two-country model with panel evidence (1960–1990) for 14 OECD countries at the country-year level. title: Sticky Prices: New Evidence from Retail Catalogs
author: Anil K. Kashyap
context: This paper analyzes semiannual catalog list prices for twelve staple retail goods sold by three U.S. mail-order firms (L.L. Bean, Orvis, REI) from 1953–1987 (with some items shorter), using item-by-item price series as the unit of observation. title: High Wage Workers and High Wage Firms
author: John M. Abowd, Francis Kramarz, David N. Margolis
context: This paper uses linked employer–employee panels for France to decompose total annual compensation into worker- and firm-level components. title: The Effect of Credit Market Competition on Lending Relationships
author: Mitchell A. Petersen, Raghuram G. Rajan
outcome: Initial loan interest rates for new firms
context: This paper examines how local bank-market concentration affects lending relationships using the 1988–89 National Survey of Small Business Finances (firms in operation as of Dec 1987), a cross-sectional sample of 3,404 U.S. small non‑financial, non‑farm firms (≤500 employees) across counties/MSAs. It exploits cross-market variation in FDIC deposit Herfindahl indices (categorized <0.10, 0.10–0.18, >0.18) and state banking regimes (branching/unit‑banking) to compare credit availability, trade‑credit behavior, and interest‑rate dynamics. Institutional context: small firms rely on local banks and regulators limit banks’ equity claims.

title: Contagion and Bank Failures During the Great Depression: The June 1932  Chicago Banking Panic
author: Charles W. Calomiris, Joseph R. Mason
outcome: Unwarranted bank failures during the panic
context: This paper examines bank failures during the Great Depression, focusing on the June 1932 Chicago banking panic. Using individual Chicago bank-level observations (stock prices, balance sheets, income statements, liability composition, and failure dates) from 1931–1932, the authors compare banks that failed during the panic, banks that failed outside the panic window, and survivors. Institutional context includes absence of deposit insurance, clearing-house and correspondent arrangements, Reconstruction Finance Corporation interventions, municipal fiscal stress and major corporate failures (Insull), and episodes of fraud (Bain chain).

title: The Causes and Effects of Liability Reform: Some Empirical Evidence
author: Thomas J. Campbell, Daniel P. Kessler, George B. Shepherd
context: This paper analyzes the effects and determinants of state-level tort liability reforms in the United States over 1969–1990. The authors compile a new panel of state tort statutes and judicial decisions matched to industry–state–year data (17 local industries plus manufacturing) from the BEA, and study how adoption of eight reforms (e.g., damage caps, contingency-fee limits, joint-and-several, comparative negligence, prejudgment interest) affected industry productivity and employment. Units are state-industry-year observations; authors exploit staggered cross-state adoption and use political/professional variables (lawyers/doctors per capita, party control, ADA scores) as instruments.

title: Supply-Side Economics in a Global Economy
author: Enrique G. Mendoza, Linda L. Tesar
treatment: Replacing income taxes with consumption taxes
context: The paper analyzes welfare effects of replacing income (capital) taxes with consumption taxes in a calibrated, open-economy framework (home and foreign countries) using a benchmark reflecting current G-7 fiscal policies. title: Local Labor Markets and Welfare Spells: Do Demand Conditions Matter?
author: Hilary Williamson Hoynes
context: This paper analyzes how local labor market conditions affected AFDC welfare spells in California using the administrative Longitudinal Database (10% sample) of monthly records, January 1987–December 1992, at the AFDC case/family level (AFDC-FG and AFDC-UP). County- and zip-code–level labor market measures (unemployment, employment, employment/population, sector earnings from UI/202 data) and 1990 Census neighborhood controls are used. For this triplet, the reported effect on the AFDC caseload is a simulation derived from the estimated discrete-time duration (logit hazard) model with county fixed effects, summarizing the implied permanent caseload change under the assumption of constant entry rates.

title: Performance Pay and Productivity
author: Edward P. Lazear
context: This paper analyzes a 19-month panel (Jan 1994–July 1995) of installers at Safelite Glass Corporation (Columbus, Ohio), using monthly person-month observations (≈31,000 good observations on ~3,700 installers) to study effects of a phased shift from hourly wages to piece-rate pay with a wage guarantee (≈$11/hr, ≈$20 per unit) instituted after a management change. The setting is commercial auto‑glass installation, with firm administrative data on units per associate per day, pay, hours, and separations; implementation was staggered across workers allowing within-worker before–after comparisons.

title: Federal Reserve Private Information and the Behavior of Interest Rates
author: Christina D. Romer, David H. Romer
context: This paper studies U.S. monthly data on Federal Reserve internal "Green Book" forecasts (1965–1991) and commercial forecasts (Blue Chip, DRI, SPF), focusing empirically on periods 1974:9–1979:9 and 1984:3–1991:12. Units are monthly forecast observations and forecast errors for the GDP deflator and real GDP; institutional setting is FOMC policy meetings, federal funds rate target changes, and press-reported Fed actions. The analysis tests whether Fed private information is signaled by monetary actions and causes revisions in market inflation expectations and the term structure.

title: Technology, Factor Supplies and International Specialization: Estimating the Neoclassical Model
author: James Harrigan
context: Using a panel of OECD manufacturing data (roughly 1970–1988, some series to 1990) for ten industrialized countries, the paper studies country×industry×year variation in sector GDP shares to estimate how Hicks‑neutral technology differences and relative factor supplies (capital, labor by education, land) jointly determine international specialization. Data sources include OECD ISDB, Penn World Tables, and Barro‑Lee; the empirical setting assumes small open economies, competitive markets, constant returns, and industry-level translog revenue functions.

title: Abortion Legalization and Child Living Circumstances: Who is the Marginal Child?""
author: Jonathan Gruber, Phillip Levine, Douglas Staiger
context: The paper estimates how U.S. state-level abortion legalization affected government welfare expenditures by tracking birth cohorts exposed to legalization (defining the “year after legalization” as 1971 in repeal states and 1976 in non-repeal states). Using cohort-level outcomes through 1994 (payments expressed in 1995 dollars), it attributes a 13,868-family reduction in the welfare caseload per cohort and computes aggregate savings (about $90 million per cohort per year and roughly $14 billion in welfare savings through 1994). Units are U.S. states, birth cohorts, families, and government welfare payments.

title: Displaced Capital
author: Valerie A. Ramey, Matthew D. Shapiro
context: This paper studies reallocation of specialized physical capital following aerospace plant closures in the post–Cold War downsizing of the late 1980s–1990s. It uses confidential auction records from three Southern California aerospace plants that discontinued operations; the unit of observation is used capital items/lots, their transaction prices, buyers (assigned to 4-digit SIC codes), and rebuild histories. The institutional setting features declining U.S. defense demand, thin resale markets, private liquidation sales versus public auctions, and geographic dispersion of buyers.

title: An Account of Global Factor Trade
author: Donald R. Davis, David E. Weinstein
context: This study tests Heckscher-Ohlin-Vanek predictions using mid-1980s (circa 1985) input-output, trade, and endowment data for ten OECD countries (Australia, Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Netherlands, United Kingdom, United States) and an aggregated Rest of World. The unit of observation is country-by-industry sectors and bilateral trade flows. The authors estimate country-specific Hicks‑neutral productivity, sectoral input coefficients, and gravity-based bilateral import demand to assess departures from factor-price equalization, specialization in tradables, and the role of trade costs in net factor service trade.

title: Individual Risk and Intergenerational Risk Sharing in an Investment-Based Social Security Program
author: Martin Feldstein, Elena Ranguelova
context: This paper studies, for a U.S. birth cohort aged 21 in 1998 (simulated 1998–2077), the distributional risk of retirement income under investment-based Personal Retirement Accounts (PRAs) for a representative individual contributing 3.1–9% of earnings to a continually rebalanced 60:40 equity–debt portfolio and annuitizing at age 67. For this triplet, results are illustrated under a nonstochastic 5.5% real log return: e.g., saving 3.1% funds the benchmark benefits, while saving 6% yields a median annuity 2.1× the benchmark and only a 17% chance of falling below it.

title: In a World Without Borders:  The Impact of Taxes on Internet Commerce

context: This paper uses late‑1997 Forrester/NPD survey data on roughly 25,000 U.S. Internet users (and ≈40,000 computer owners) across about 351 city–state locations to estimate how local retail sales tax rates affect individual online purchasing and spending. title: The Returns to Skill in the United States across the Twentieth Century
author: Claudia Goldin, Lawrence F. Katz
context: This empirical study examines U.S. wage structure and returns to schooling across the long twentieth century (roughly 1890–1995), combining individual-level data (the 1915 Iowa State Census sample, IPUMS 1940–1960), matched manufacturing wage distributions (1890 vs. c.1940), and county-level agricultural outcomes (1915–1925). title: Learning and Forgetting:  The Dynamics of Aircraft Production
author: C. Lanier Benkard
context: This paper analyzes unit-level direct labor hours for all 250 Lockheed L-1011 commercial airliners produced in the United States (Burbank and Palmdale plants) between 1970 and 1984. Using plane-level completion dates and model type (-1/-100/-200 versus -500), the author studies how cumulative production, production rates, union "displacement rights" and model introductions affect learning-by-doing, organizational forgetting (experience depreciation), and within-firm spillovers. The setting is a volatile commercial aircraft market with union rules, simultaneous multi-model production, and large sunk development costs that shape production scheduling and productivity dynamics.

context: This paper examines how information technology, workplace organization, and human capital jointly affect firm-level labor demand and productivity in the United States. title: Multinational Firms:  Reconciling Theory and Evidence
author: James R. Markusen, Keith E. Maskus
context: This paper empirically examines how parent- and host-country characteristics shape foreign affiliate production (local sales versus export sales) using annual panel data for 1986–1994 on non-bank manufacturing affiliate sales between the United States and 36 other countries. context: This paper uses laboratory and field-style experiments conducted with Harvard undergraduates in the late 1990s (recruited during the first week of an introductory economics course, with experimental sessions 3–4 weeks later) in Cambridge, MA. title: The Effects of Urban Concentration on Economic Growth
author: J. Vernon Henderson
context: This paper uses a cross-country panel of about 80–100 countries over 1960–1995 (five-year intervals) to estimate how national urban concentration—measured by primacy (the largest metro area’s share of national urban population)—affects economic growth. The unit of observation is the country-period; analyses control for income, human capital, investment, fertility, openness, federalism, and transport infrastructure (road and waterway density). The study exploits panel GMM/differenced estimation to address endogeneity while also examining policy levers that shape primacy.

title: Can Falling Supply Explain the Rising Return to College for Younger Men? A Cohort-Based Analysis
author: David Card, Thomas Lemieux
treatment: Age-group specific relative supply of college workers
context: This paper analyzes labor-market data from the United States (1959–1996), the United Kingdom (1974–1996), and Canada (1981–1996), using repeated cross-sections (Census, CPS, GHS) of male workers by 5-year age/cohort groups to study how inter-cohort changes in college versus high‑school relative supply affected the college–high school wage gap. author: Brigitte C. Madrian, Dennis F. Shea

title: The World Technology Frontier
author: Francesco Caselli, Wilbur John Coleman II
context: This paper analyzes cross-country differences in factor-specific efficiencies and the choice of "appropriate" technologies using a cross-section of 52 countries in the late 1980s (GDP and capital for 1988, schooling 1985). The unit of observation is the country (per-worker GDP, physical capital, skilled/unskilled labor aggregates). The authors combine PPP-adjusted GDP and perpetual-inventory capital estimates (Summers–Heston/Hall–Jones), Barro–Lee schooling, and Bils–Klenow returns to structurally estimate a technology-frontier model while assuming a common world interest rate and country-specific adoption barriers.

title: On the Nature of Capital Adjustment Costs
author: Russell W. Cooper, John C. Haltiwanger
context: This paper analyzes a balanced panel of about 7,000 U.S. manufacturing plants continuously operating from 1972–1988 (Longitudinal Research Database). author: Josh Angrist

title: The Aging Population and the Size of the Welfare State
author: Assaf Razin, Efraim Sadka, Phillip Swagel
context: This paper studies how population aging affects labor tax rates and per‑capita social transfers using an overlapping‑generations political‑economy model and country‑level data for the United States and 12 Western European countries from 1965–1992. title: Liquidity Risk and Expected Stock Returns
author: Lubos Pastor, Robert F. Stambaugh
context: This result is estimated using U.S. common stocks (NYSE, AMEX, NASDAQ) over 1966–1999. The authors construct a monthly aggregate liquidity innovation from signed-volume return-reversal regressions, predict stock-level liquidity betas, and form annual decile portfolios by predicted liquidity beta. author: Edward Miguel, Michael Kremer
outcome: School participation among untreated pupils in treated schools
context: This empirical study evaluates a randomized, phased-in school-based deworming program in Budalangi and Funyula divisions of Busia District, western Kenya, during 1998–1999 (with a later rollout in 2001). title: The Impacts of Environmental Regulations on Industrial Activity: Evidence from the 1970 & 1977 Clean Air Act Amendments and the Census of Manufactures
author: Michael Greenstone
context: This paper studies the effects of the 1970 and 1977 U.S. Clean Air Act Amendments on manufacturing using plant-level Census of Manufactures data from 1967–1987. It exploits county-level, pollutant-specific attainment/nonattainment designations for four criteria pollutants across 3,070 counties and 1.75 million plant observations; polluting plants in nonattainment counties faced stricter plant-specific regulation. The unit of analysis is individual manufacturing plants; identification leverages cross-sectional and temporal variation in county nonattainment status and industry emitting status to estimate regulation impacts on employment, capital, and shipments.

title: The Effect of Education on Crime: Evidence from Prison Inmates, Arrests, and Self-Reports
author: Lance Lochner, Enrico Moretti
context: This paper estimates the causal effect of completing high school on criminal behavior in the United States by exploiting cross-state and cohort variation in compulsory-attendance laws. The key policy variation is historical changes in state compulsory-schooling/attendance laws used as an instrument for graduation, with OLS/IV comparisons and robustness checks across data sources and crime categories.

context: The paper evaluates the causal impact of West Bengal’s 1998 policy that randomly reserved one-third of Gram Panchayat (GP) chief (Pradhan) positions for women. title: Estimation of a Dynamic Auction Game
author: Mireia Jofre-Bonet, Martin Pesendorfer
context: This paper estimates a dynamic first-price repeated procurement auction with capacity constraints using California Department of Transportation highway paving auction data from May 1996 to May 1999. Units are bidders (classified as regular and fringe) and contract-level sealed bids across 2,207 awarded projects. Institutional features include reserve prices, sealed-bid awarding to the low bidder, multi-month contract durations creating backlog and capacity effects, and observable contract characteristics. The authors use a structural two-stage estimator and reduced-form regressions to quantify backlog effects and efficiency losses.

title: Women, War and Wages: The Effect of Female Labor Supply on the Wage Structure at Mid-Century
author: Daron Acemoglu, David H. Autor, David Lyle
context: The paper exploits World War II as an exogenous shock (primarily 1940–1950, with checks into 1947–1960) across the continental U.S. to study how wartime male mobilization altered female labor supply and thereby affected female and male weekly wages, skill premia, and male inequality. Using individual-level IPUMS Census samples (1940, 1950, 1960), CPS/Social Security match data, and state-level aggregates for ~47 states, the authors leverage cross-state differences in draft/enlistment rates (and their demographic predictors) with state fixed-effects comparisons to identify causal impacts.

title: Using Mandated Speed Limits to Measure the Value of a Statistical Life
author: Orley Ashenfelter, Michael Greenstone
outcome: Hours required to travel a mile
context: Study examines the effect of states' adoption of a 65 mph maximum speed limit (the 1987 federal change that allowed states to raise rural interstate limits) on hours required to travel a mile (the reciprocal of average speed times vehicle miles traveled). Using state-by-roadtype-by-year panel data for 1982–93 and focusing on rural interstates (including 21 adopting states with complete post-1987 speed data), the paper fits the reduced-form equation (12b) on pooled years and finds about a 4% decrease in hours per mile on rural interstates after adoption, with no effect on urban interstates or rural arterials.

title: In Search of the Holy Grail: Policy Convergence, Experimentation, and Economic Performance
author: Sharun Mukand, Dani Rodrik
context: Analyzes post-socialist countries’ policy choices and economic performance after the collapse of socialism (early 1990s onward), using countries as the unit of observation. Empirical tests focus on former socialist European countries transitioning to market institutions, taking Western Europe (proxied by Brussels) as the leader to emulate; geographic distance to Brussels is used as an inverse proxy for suitability of European-style institutions. Background: a theoretical model of policy imitation versus experimentation, transparency and corruption; outcomes include post-transition growth, reform indices, and corruption measures with controls for other determinants.

title: What Can Be Learned from Skeletons that Might Interest Economists, Historians and Other Social Scientists?
author: Richard H. Steckel
context: This paper analyzes 12,520 skeletons from 65 localities across the Western Hemisphere over the past several millennia (including 4,078 individuals from 23 pre‑Columbian sites in North, Central and South America). Using individual skeletal measures aggregated to community/locality level, it constructs a seven‑component morbidity-based health index (age-weighted using a Model West reference life table) and compares health across settlement types (mobile, village, urban) and historical environments to assess how settlement size and related conditions affected community health.

title: Consumption Risk and Expected Stock Returns
author: Jonathan A. Parker
context: Using U.S. quarterly data (1947 Q2–1998 Q1), the paper evaluates how aggregate and household-level consumption risk (real per‑capita chain‑weighted nondurable consumption) relates to expected stock returns (value‑weighted NYSE market returns and Fama–French portfolios). Within a (C‑)CAPM framework it contrasts contemporaneous and long‑horizon consumption betas (S quarters ahead) and examines consumption of stockholders using the Consumer Expenditure Survey. The institutional setting is U.S. financial markets with the three‑month T‑bill as the risk‑free rate, emphasizing consumption smoothing and limited stock‑market participation.

title: Are Idle Hands the Devil's Workshop? Incapacitation, Concentration and Juvenile Crime
author: Brian A. Jacob, Lars Lefgren
context: This paper analyzes daily incident- and arrest-level crime data (NIBRS) for 29 U.S. jurisdictions during 1995–1999, merged with school-district calendars. The unit of observation is city-day counts of juvenile offenders; the setting is U.S. public school calendars (teacher in-service days, holidays, breaks, summer). The study exploits plausibly exogenous variation in in-service and idiosyncratic break days to estimate short-run effects of school being in session on juvenile property and violent crime, controlling for city*year*month and day-of-week effects and testing robustness with NCVS checks and weekly aggregation.

title: Bank Integration and State Business Cycles
author: Donald Morgan, Bertrand Rime, Philip Strahan
context: This triplet focuses on U.S. state-level small-firm employment growth volatility using annual state-year observations over the deregulation era; small-firm employment (establishments with <20 employees) is drawn from County Business Patterns and the growth-rate series effectively covers 1978–1994. The paper links volatility to banking integration—the share of state bank assets owned by multi-state bank holding companies—exploiting staggered state-level interstate-banking deregulation and controlling for industry composition, and state and year fixed effects.

title: The Labor Demand Curve is Downward Sloping: Reexamining the Impact of Immigration on the Labor Market
author: George J. Borjas
context: Using U.S. microdata (1960–1990 Decennial Census PUMS and pooled 1999–2001 CPS), the paper studies how immigration altered wages and labor supply of prime‑age men (ages 18–64) grouped by education and experience across U.S. labor markets (nationally and by state/region) over 1960–2000. It exploits variation in immigrant shares across schooling‑experience cells, assumes similarly educated workers with different experience are imperfect substitutes, and combines reduced‑form regressions with structural CES demand exercises to quantify wage and employment effects.

title: The Regulation of Labor
author: Simeon Djankov, Rafael La Porta, Florencio Lopez-de-Silane, Andrei Shleifer, Juan Botero
context: This paper analyzes cross-country variation in labor-market regulation using detailed indices of employment law, collective-bargaining law, and social‑security law measured around 1997 for 85 countries. Units are countries; political controls use the fraction of years that executives and legislatures were left/center between 1975–1995 (and robustness to 1928–1995). Main outcomes include unofficial-economy size, labor-force participation, unemployment (especially ages 20–24), and relative wages.

context: This paper studies 71 non-transition countries (sample based on Maddex 1995), relating constitutional provisions — judicial independence (tenure of supreme and administrative judges, case law) and constitutional review (rigidity, judicial review) — to mid-1990s measures of economic and political freedom (property rights c.1997, business entry procedures, employment regulation, government bank ownership c.1995, democracy and human/political rights mid-1990s). Units are countries; identification leverages persistent constitutional variation, legal origins, former-colony subsamples, and controls for latitude, ethnolinguistic fractionalization, and GDP per capita.

title: Is the Social Security Trust Fund Worth Anything?
author: Kent Smetters
context: This paper analyzes U.S. federal fiscal accounts using annual data from 1949–2002 to test whether Social Security off‑budget surpluses reduced debt held by the public or instead financed larger on‑budget spending/tax cuts. The unit of observation is yearly national budget aggregates (on‑budget and off‑budget primary surpluses, trust fund assets), in the U.S. institutional setting that includes the 1969–70 adoption of a unified budget, payroll‑tax increases starting in 1983, and Social Security Trustees’ projections through the 2010s–2040s.

title: A New Measure of Monetary Shocks: Derivation and Implications
author: Christina D. Romer, David H. Romer
context: This paper analyzes U.S. monetary policy during 1969–1996. It constructs exogenous monetary shocks from intended federal-funds-rate changes around FOMC meetings using Federal Reserve Greenbook forecasts, internal expected-funds memos, and FOMC narrative records. Units of analysis are FOMC meetings and monthly macro series (industrial production, PPI). The institutional setting is Federal Reserve policymaking across Burns–Volcker–Greenspan eras, exploiting meeting-timed policy intentions and residualized shocks to estimate causal effects of monetary policy on output and prices.

title: How Do Hospitals Respond to Price Changes?
author: Leemore S. Dafny
context: Using U.S. Medicare inpatient data (20% MedPAR sample) from 1985–1991, this paper studies hospital responses to an exogenous 1988 HCFA reform that removed the “age over 69” qualifier from DRG definitions under Medicare’s Prospective Payment System. title: Why the Apple Doesn't Fall Far: Understanding Intergenerational Transmission of Human Capital
author: Sandra E. Black, Paul J. Devereux, Kjell G. Salvanes
context: This analysis uses Norwegian administrative and census registers linking parents (born 1947–1958) to the municipality in which they grew up to estimate how the 1960–1972 staggered reform that raised compulsory schooling from 7 to 9 years affected parental educational attainment. The reform was implemented at the municipality level and primarily increased attainment in the lower tail: the share with fewer than 9 years fell from about 12% to under 3%, producing a spike at 9 years.

title: Why the Apple Doesn't Fall Far: Understanding Intergenerational Transmission of Human Capital
author: Sandra E. Black, Paul J. Devereux, Kjell G. Salvanes
context: This estimate uses Norwegian administrative and census data exploiting the staggered 1960–1972 municipal implementation of a reform raising compulsory schooling from 7 to 9 years as an instrument for parental education. It focuses on parents born 1947–1958 (linked to their municipality of upbringing) and their adult children (aged 20–35 in 2000); the causal IV (2SLS) estimates for fathers are primarily identified using the reform's effects on parents in the lower tail (≤9 years) of the education distribution.

title: Air Pollution and Infant Health: What Can We Learn From California's Recent Experience
author: Janet Currie, Matthew Neidell
context: This paper analyzes individual-level birth, fetal-death, and infant-mortality records in California over the 1990s (approximately 1989–2000), linking pregnancies and infants (by maternal 5-digit ZIP) to ambient pollution measures for four criteria pollutants (O3, CO, PM10, NO2) from monitoring stations. The institutional setting is California during a period of declining pollution and active air-quality regulation. The authors exploit within–ZIP-code temporal variation (controlling for ZIP fixed effects, month/year seasonality, weather) to estimate prenatal and postnatal pollution impacts on birth outcomes and infant mortality.

title: What do Aggregate Consumption Euler Equations Say about the Capital Income Tax Burden?
author: Casey B. Mulligan
context: This paper uses U.S. aggregate annual data (primarily 1947–1997) to study how capital income taxation affects the wedge between expected pre-tax returns on the capital stock and consumption growth. Units are national aggregates—BEA measures of pre-tax and after-tax capital returns, per-capita nondurable and services consumption, and capital-income tax revenue (federal, state, local). The analysis relies on consumption Euler equations, VARs to form expectations, and TSLS estimates to infer capital supply elasticity and tax incidence in the mid-to-late 20th century United States.

title: Thirty Years of Current Account Imbalances, Current Account Reversals and Sudden Stops
author: Sebastian Edwards
context: Using annual country-year data for 157 countries over 1970–2001, this paper studies current-account imbalances, large deficit “reversals,” and “sudden stops.” The unit of observation is the country-year across six regions (industrial, Latin America/Caribbean, Asia, Africa, MENA, Eastern Europe). Analyses relate lagged external debt, reserves, short-term debt, and credit growth to reversal probability and estimate reversal impacts on GDP growth, contextualized by 1970s oil shocks, the 1980s debt crisis, 1990s currency crises, IMF programs, and varying exchange-rate/dollarization regimes.

title: Serial Default and the Paradox" of Rich to Poor Capital Flows"
author: Carmen M. Reinhart, Kenneth S. Rogoff
outcome: Equity and direct foreign investment flows
context: This paper examines sovereign serial default and its link to rich‑to‑poor capital flows using historical and cross‑country data (post‑1500 history with emphasis on post‑1946 outcomes and 1998–2002 income averages). The unit of observation is countries (sovereigns) worldwide, using country‑level shares of years in default, PPP‑adjusted per‑capita GDP, external debt ratios, and international equity issuance (1983–2003). The institutional setting centers on sovereign external debt markets, political and contract‑enforcement risk, and differences between emerging‑market and OECD borrowing environments.

title: Business Cycle Accounting
author: V.V. Chari, Patrick J. Kehoe, Ellen McGrattan
context: This paper analyzes U.S. aggregate business cycle episodes — principally the Great Depression (1929–39), the 1982 recession (1979–85), and the postwar period (1959:1–2004:3) — using national-level time series on output, labor, investment and government consumption. It maps frictions (credit, sticky wages, monopoly power) into four time-varying wedges (efficiency, labor, investment, government consumption) within a stochastic growth prototype, estimates a vector AR(1) process for wedges from macro data, and feeds measured wedges into calibrated structural models to assess their contributions to fluctuations.

title: The Impact of Nearly Universal Insurance Coverage on Health Care Utilization and Health: Evidence from Medicare
author: David Card, Carlos Dobkin, Nicole Maestas
context: This paper analyzes U.S. microdata—pooled NHIS (1992–2001) and BRFSS (1998–2002) surveys, state hospital discharge records (California and Florida, 1995–1999/2000), and national death files—to study individuals and hospital admissions around the Medicare eligibility cutoff. Exploiting the institutional rule that most people become eligible for Medicare at age 65 (Part A/B availability subject to work-history rules), the authors estimate how the near-universal jump in coverage at 65 affects access, utilization, procedures, and self-reported and mortality outcomes for people just below and above 65.

title: Which Countries Have State Religions?
author: Robert J. Barro, Rachel M. McCleary
context: This paper analyzes determinants of official state religions for 188 countries using historical indicators of state-religion status in 1900 and observed outcomes in 1970 and 2000. The unit is the country; analyses account for major regime changes (independence, territorial splits, adoption/ending of Communism), measures of religious adherence concentration and faith shares, colonial and legal origins, and macro controls (per-capita GDP, region). The focus is on persistence and causal effects shaping establishment, removal, and reintroduction of state religions over the 20th century.

title: Earnings Manipulation and Managerial Investment Decisions: Evidence from Sponsored Pension Plans
author: Daniel Bergstresser, Mihir A. Desai, Joshua Rauh
context: Studies US publicly traded firms sponsoring defined-benefit pension plans over 1991–2002 (≈3,247 firms, 19,325 firm‑years), using Compustat, SDC M&A data, ExecComp, Pensions & Investments and IRS Form 5500. title: Asymmetric Cycles
author: Boyan Jovanovic
treatment: Random adjustment costs in technology adoption
context: The paper develops and estimates a structural model of technology adoption with costly retooling using U.S. data. It fits the model to U.S. real GDP per capita from 1790–2000 (five- and ten-year intervals) to estimate growth dynamics and uses plant-level TFP conditional distributions (e.g., 1982–1987 manufacturing plant data) to illustrate cross-sectional skewness. Units of analysis are the aggregate economy (per-capita GDP) and individual firms/plants; the framework assumes technological commitment, random adjustment shocks to required skills, and costly within-firm skill retooling.

context: This paper develops a political-agency model and empirically tests it using state-level panel data on governors' environmental policy across the 48 continental U.S. states from 1960–2000 (with robustness checks for 1970–2000). title: Systemic Crises and Growth
author: Romain Ranciere, Aaron Tornell, Frank Westermann
context: Using cross-country annual data (primarily 1961–2000, sample of ~58 countries aggregated into non‑overlapping decades), the paper links systemic financial risk—proxied by skewness of real bank‑credit growth and multiple crisis indexes—to per‑capita GDP growth and investment. The empirical tests exploit cross‑country and decade variation to evaluate a theoretical model where liberalization plus moderate enforceability and bailout guarantees induce systemic risk‑taking.

title: From Education to Democracy?
author: Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson, James A. Robinson, Pierre Yared
context: This paper studies country-level panels (about 108 countries) over the postwar period (mainly 1965–2000 at five-year intervals, with 10-year checks) to test whether increases in average years of adult schooling lead to democratization. The authors exploit within-country variation using time and country fixed effects and conduct subsample and robustness checks (e.g., excluding socialist, Sub‑Saharan African, or Muslim-majority countries).

author: Jens Ludwig, Douglas L. Miller

context: Uses the OEO 1965 targeting of grant‑writing assistance to the 300 poorest 1960 counties to compare county‑level Head Start spending per 4‑year‑old in 1968 and 1972. title: Life-Cycle Variation in the Association between Current and Lifetime Earnings
author: Steven Haider, Gary Solon
context: The paper uses Social Security earnings histories (1951–1991) linked to the Health and Retirement Study for U.S. men born 1931–1933 to estimate Tobit-based joint distributions and simulate uncensored lifetime earnings. Applying these estimates to the intergenerational mobility regression (son’s log lifetime earnings on father’s log lifetime earnings), the paper shows that right-side measurement error from using short-run proxies for fathers’ lifetime earnings induces attenuation (downward bias) in OLS; this conclusion is based on estimated θ_t (figures 2–3).

title: Democracy and Development: The Devil in the Details
author: Torsten Persson, Guido Tabellini
context: The paper uses annual country-year data on about 150 countries (main analyses 1960–2000; extended 1850–2000 for expectation analysis) to study effects of regime changes on log per-capita income and investment. It exploits episodes of democratization, autocracy, and economic liberalization (Polity2; Sachs–Warner liberalization), variation in forms of government and electoral rules (presidential vs parliamentary; majoritarian vs proportional), and controls for wars and former Soviet-bloc transitions; expected regime-change hazards (democratic capital) are modeled.

title: Democracy and Development: The Devil in the Details
author: Torsten Persson, Guido Tabellini
context: Using annual country-year data, the paper analyzes how the estimated hazard rate of regime change affects per-capita economic growth by estimating panel regressions with country and year fixed effects. The reported results restrict attention to observations within regimes (separately for democratic and autocratic years), using the hazard rate derived from a model of "democratic capital" over 1850–2000 (robustness over 1960–2000 noted). Controls include lagged income and war dummies; outcomes include growth and investment.

title: The Unequal Effects of Liberalization: Evidence from Dismantling the License Raj in India
author: Philippe Aghion, Robin Burgess, Stephen Redding, Fabrizio Zilibotti
context: This paper studies the effects of dismantling India’s “license raj” and concurrent trade liberalization on registered manufacturing across 16 Indian states over 1980–1997. title: Disease and Development: The Effect of Life Expectancy on Economic Growth
author: Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson
context: This cross-country study analyzes country-level effects of the mid-20th-century “international epidemiological transition” (primarily 1940–1980) across about 59 countries (decadal country-year observations). The unit is the country; outcomes include life expectancy, population, total births, GDP and GDP per capita. Identification exploits exogenous timing of global health interventions (e.g., antibiotics, DDT, WHO campaigns) interacted with pre-1940 disease-specific mortality rates. The core institutional background is the global diffusion of medical and public-health technologies after WWII and resulting differential mortality declines by baseline disease burden.

title: Sources of Advantageous Selection: Evidence from the Medigap Insurance Market
author: Hanming Fang, Michael P. Keane, Dan Silverman
context: This study (Fang, Keane, Silverman, 2006) analyzes selection into Medigap supplemental insurance among U.S. Medicare beneficiaries (age 65+) using Medicare Current Beneficiary Survey data (circa 1999–2001/2000–2001) and Health and Retirement Study waves (2000–2002). The unit of analysis is individual Medicare beneficiaries across U.S. states where Medigap pricing and standardized plans and a six-month open-enrollment rule limit risk-based pricing. The paper leverages detailed medical expenditure records, rich health measures, and HRS measures (income, cognition, risk aversion, expectations) to study why healthier or lower-risk seniors purchase Medigap.

title: Tracing the Impact of Bank Liquidity Shocks: Evidence from an Emerging Market
author: Atif Mian, Asim Ijaz Khwaja
context: This paper studies how bank liquidity shocks following the unanticipated May 1998 India–Pakistan nuclear tests affected corporate lending and firm distress in Pakistan. Using the State Bank of Pakistan loan-level panel (July 1996–March 2000) covering ~22,000 loans to ~18,600 firms and 42 commercial banks, the authors exploit cross-bank variation in exposure to dollar deposit accounts and pre/post comparisons to isolate bank lending and firm borrowing channels. title: The Spike at Benefit Exhaustion: Leaving the Unemployment System or Starting a New Job?
author: David Card, Raj Chetty, Andrea Weber
context: Using Austrian social security administrative records for involuntary job losses from 1981–2001, the paper analyzes about 92,969 individuals aged 20–50 to study exit hazards around unemployment insurance (UI) benefit exhaustion. Austria’s UI rules provide 20 or 30 weeks of benefits depending on months worked in the prior five years (36-month threshold), alongside severance pay rules and means-tested post-exhaustion assistance. The analysis contrasts registered-unemployment duration and time-to-next-job (including recalls) to assess whether spikes at benefit expiration reflect true re-employment or exits from the register.

title: The Spike at Benefit Exhaustion: Leaving the Unemployment System or Starting a New Job?
author: David Card, Raj Chetty, Andrea Weber
context: Using Austrian social security administrative records for involuntary job losses from 1981–2001, the paper analyzes about 92,969 individuals aged 20–50 to study exit hazards around unemployment insurance (UI) benefit exhaustion. Austria’s UI rules provide 20 or 30 weeks of benefits depending on months worked in the prior five years (36-month threshold), alongside severance pay rules and means-tested post-exhaustion assistance. The analysis contrasts registered-unemployment duration and time-to-next-job (including recalls) to assess whether spikes at benefit expiration reflect true re-employment or exits from the register.

title: Estimating Trade Flows: Trading Partners and Trading Volumes
author: Elhanan Helpman, Marc Melitz, Yona Rubinstein
context: Using bilateral trade data for 158 countries over 1970–1997 (with focused analyses for 1986 and the 1980s), the paper examines exporter–importer country-pair outcomes (whether a link exists and export volumes). It embeds a heterogeneous‑firms model with fixed and variable export costs to decompose effects of trade frictions (distance, tariffs, WTO/FTA membership, common language, borders, currency unions, entry regulation) into intensive (exports per exporter) and extensive (number of exporters) margins. Empirical identification exploits exporter/importer fixed effects, a Probit selection for trading links, Heckman corrections, and structural counterfactuals.

title: Identifying Technology Spillovers and Product Market Rivalry
author: Nicholas Bloom, Mark Schankerman, John Van Reenen
treatment: R&D by firms close in technology space
context: This paper empirically separates technology spillovers from product-market rivalry using a panel of U.S. publicly listed firms (715 firms) matched between Compustat (accounting/segment data, 1980–2001) and USPTO patent data (patents 1963–1999). The authors construct technology closeness from patent-class shares and product-market closeness from four-digit segment sales (Compustat and BVD), exploiting within-firm time variation with fixed effects, lags and industry controls.

title: Imported Intermediate Inputs and Domestic Product Growth: Evidence from India
author: Pinelopi K. Goldberg, Amit Khandelwal, Nina Pavcnik, Petia Topalova
context: This paper studies India’s 1991 trade liberalization and its effects on firm product scope during 1989–1997. Using a panel of ~2,927 manufacturing firms (Prowess) with firm–product data and detailed HS import data (1987–2000) mapped via India’s 1993–94 input–output matrix, the authors analyze how differential, unanticipated declines in input tariffs across industries affected imports of intermediate varieties and domestic firms’ new product introductions. The setting exploits sudden tariff cuts, industry heterogeneity, and firm fixed effects to identify causal links between imported input variety/prices and domestic product growth.

title: An Anatomy of International Trade: Evidence from French Firms
author: Jonathan Eaton, Samuel Kortum, Francis Kramarz
context: This paper studies French manufacturing firms using firm-level sales in 1986 for 229,900 firms (34,035 exporters) across 113 destinations (including France). title: Identifying Supply and Demand Elasticities of Agricultural Commodities: Implications for the US Ethanol Mandate
author: Michael J. Roberts, Wolfram Schlenker
context: Using country–crop–year data from roughly 1961–2007 (demand estimates through 2003), the paper studies worldwide markets for maize, wheat, rice and soybeans aggregated into calories. Units are country–crop yields, harvested area, inventories and world caloric prices (Chicago futures and US farm prices). Within a competitive storage framework, it exploits weather- and yield-induced shocks to identify supply, demand and inventory dynamics and quantifies the causal impact of US ethanol policy (mid-2000s Renewable Fuel Standards diverting ≈5% of world calories) on prices, quantities, and land use.

title: What Goods Do Countries Trade? A Quantitative Exploration of Ricardo's Ideas
author: Arnaud Costinot, Dave Donaldson, Ivana Komunjer
context: Using cross-industry, bilateral trade and productivity data for the year 1997, this paper studies how country–industry productivity differences shape exports and welfare. title: Competitive Equilibrium in Markets for Votes

context: This paper develops a theory of competitive vote markets and tests it in laboratory experiments conducted at Caltech (June 2009) with undergraduate subjects forming small committees (n=5 and n=9). In the experiment, subjects (units) were privately assigned valuations (1–1000) and preferred alternatives and participated in a two-stage process—a 2-minute continuous multi-unit double-auction vote-trading stage followed by majority voting—across repeated rounds and market parameterizations. author: James Andreoni, Charles Sprenger
context: Laboratory experiment at the University of California, San Diego (April 2009) with 80 undergraduate campus-resident subjects. title: The Impact of Jury Race in Criminal Trials
author: Shamena Anwar, Patrick Bayer, Randi Hjalmarsson
context: This paper studies all felony jury trials with jury selection beginning in Lake County (Mar 2000–Apr 2010) and Sarasota County (Jan 2004–Jun 2009), Florida. title: Railroads of the Raj: Estimating the Impact of Transportation Infrastructure
author: Dave Donaldson
context: Uses newly-digitized archival data on colonial India (primarily 1870–1930, with some series 1861–1930 and trade flows 1880–1920) to estimate how the British-built railroad network affected district-level agricultural welfare. The study analyzes 235 districts (and 45 trade blocks) and commodity-level flows and prices for ~17 crops and region-specific salt types, combining retail prices, annual output, daily rainfall from meteorological stations, and a mapped rail network (20 km segments with opening years). Institutional background: government-planned rail expansion (often military-motivated) transformed transport modes and trade costs.

title: Going to a Better School: Effects and Behavioral Responses
author: Cristian Pop-Eleches, Miguel Urquiola
context: This triplet concerns within-track, class-level variation in Romania using the surveyed cohorts (students entering high school in 2005–2007 in the sampled towns). title: Credit Market Consequences of Improved Personal Identification: Field Experimental Evidence from Malawi
author: Xavier Giné, Jessica Goldberg, Dean Yang
context: This randomized field experiment (baseline Sept 2007; treatment and loan season 2007–08; follow-up Aug–Nov 2008) was conducted in rural Malawi (Dedza, Mchinji, Dowa, Kasungu) among smallholder farmers organized in clubs applying for in-kind paprika input loans (3,206 applicants; 1,147 borrowers). Partner institutions were the Malawi Rural Finance Corporation (lender) and Cheetah Paprika (buyer). In this setting with weak formal identification and limited formal credit, fingerprinting of applicants aimed to strengthen identification and the credibility of lenders’ dynamic (future-credit) incentives; the reported effect on loan size is conditional on borrowers who took loans.

title: The Long-Run Effects of the Scramble for Africa
author: Stelios Michalopoulos, Elias Papaioannou
context: This empirical study evaluates long-run effects of the Scramble for Africa (late 19th-century colonial border drawing) by comparing historical ethnic homelands (Murdock 1959) that were split by modern borders to those that were not. Main outcomes span georeferenced political violence (ACLED 1997–2013; UCDP GED 1989–2010), ethnic political status over the post‑independence era (EPR), and household-level welfare (DHS). title: Aiding Conflict: The Impact of U.S. Food Aid on Civil War
author: Nathan Nunn, Nancy Qian
context: This paper uses annual country‑year data for 134 non‑OECD countries from 1972–2006 to estimate how U.S. wheat food aid (PL‑480/USDA shipments) affects civil conflict incidence, onset and duration. Outcomes are civil and interstate armed conflict (UCDP/PRIO); analyses include panel regressions, IV 2SLS, and hazard models for conflict duration.

title: Ambiguous Business Cycles
author: Cosmin Ilut, Martin Schneider
context: This paper estimates a medium-scale DSGE model for the United States using quarterly macro data (1984Q1–2010Q1) to quantify how time-varying ambiguity (agents’ changing confidence about productivity) drives business cycles. title: Chiefs: Elite Control of Civil Society and Economic Development in Sierra Leone
author: Daron Acemoglu, Tristan Reed, James A. Robinson
context: This paper studies long-run effects of colonial chieftaincy institutions in Sierra Leone by exploiting variation in the number of “ruling families” per chiefdom set under British indirect rule around 1896–1920. The analysis uses 149 chiefdoms and individuals (households, children) matched to chiefdoms, drawing on the 2004 and 1963 censuses, 2008 DHS, 2007 NPS and 1898–1902 tax records. The institutional setting centers on lifetime paramount chiefs, tribal authorities, land custodianship and civil‑society capture; the authors argue historical family counts are plausibly exogenous and estimate effects on education, health, employment and social capital.

title: Subways, Strikes, and Slowdowns: The Impacts of Public Transit on Traffic Congestion
author: Michael L. Anderson
context: This study analyzes the short-run impact of a 35-day Los Angeles County MTA strike (Oct 14–Nov 18, 2003) that halted bus and rail service. Using hourly loop-detector data on freeway speeds and minutes-per-mile delay across major Los Angeles freeways during weekday peak hours, the paper studies detector-by-hour outcomes to estimate how ceased transit service affected congestion. It combines a calibrated commuter-choice model (Los Angeles parameters) with a regression-discontinuity design using date as the running variable, detector fixed effects, and falsification/placebo tests against nearby counties and a 2004 placebo period.

context: This paper analyzes the US nonfinancial corporate sector using quarterly postwar U.S. data (1959Q1–2011Q3) to estimate a business-cycle DSGE model with endogenous firm financing and ambiguity-averse households. context: This paper studies U.S. manufacturing establishments using confidential Census plant-level data (ASM/CMF/LBD) mainly over 1972–2011, with industry and aggregate analyses extending to 1947–2015 and TFP innovations through 2009. Units are individual establishments (aggregated to 4-digit NAICS industries, sectors, and the private economy). The authors estimate Solow-residual (TFP) shocks via panel methods and nonparametrically/parametrically regress employment growth on those shocks to identify asymmetric (concave) hiring/firing responses across the business cycle, including the 2008–09 Great Recession.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions

title: Why Do People Give? Testing Pure and Impure Altruism
author: Mark Ottoni-Wilhelm, Lise Vesterlund, Huan Xie
context: Laboratory experiment at the University of Pittsburgh with 85 undergraduate participants (six sessions). In a within-subject design each participant made six allocation decisions between own consumption and donating to an individualized charity; the participant’s own endowment (own income) was exogenously varied across budgets ($40 or $46) to identify income effects. Budgets also varied the foundation’s fixed donation (giving-by-others); budget order and the paid decision were randomized and procedures were double-blind. The outcome is dollars contributed to buy books for a paired child.

title: Transition to Clean Technology
author: Daron Acemoglu, Ufuk Akcigit, Douglas Hanley, William Kerr
context: This paper combines a micro-founded endogenous-growth model with firm-level estimation using U.S. energy-sector microdata from 1975–2004. It analyzes 1,576 innovative firms (6,228 firm-period observations) using Census LBD and Economic Census records, NSF R&D survey data, and USPTO patents to study firm R&D, patents, production, employment, entry/exit, and emissions. The structural model contrasts clean versus fossil-fuel (dirty) technologies, is calibrated to carbon-cycle dynamics, and evaluates policy counterfactuals (carbon taxes and clean-research subsidies) for production, innovation direction, and welfare.

title: The Skill Complementarity of Broadband Internet
author: Anders Akerman, Ingvil Gaarder, Magne Mogstad
context: This paper studies Norway during 2001–2007 (firm and worker data span 2000–2008), exploiting a government broadband rollout (Høykom) that progressively installed local access points across 428 municipalities. Using linked administrative employer–employee registers, firm surveys of joint-stock firms, and municipality-level household broadband availability, it examines how increased broadband availability and subsequent firm adoption affected wages, employment, and firm value added for skilled versus unskilled workers. The staged, Telenor-operated rollout with limited public funding provides plausibly exogenous spatial–temporal variation for causal identification.

title: News Shocks in Open Economies: Evidence from Giant Oil Discoveries
author: Rabah Arezki, Valerie A. Ramey, Liugang Sheng
context: The paper uses a country-year panel (up to 130 countries, 1970–2012; baseline regressions 1980–2012), treating giant oil discovery announcements (NPV as percent of GDP) as plausibly exogenous news shocks with a typical 4–6 year lag and estimating dynamic responses via panel distributed-lag/event-study regressions with country and year fixed effects. For the real exchange rate specifically, the theoretical model omits a non-tradeable sector (so provides no formal prediction), and empirically the authors examine CPI- and GDP-deflator-based RERs, finding small, imprecise, statistically insignificant appreciation in the first five years after discovery.

title: Production Networks, Geography and Firm Performance
author: Andrew B. Bernard, Andreas Moxnes, Yukiko U. Saito
context: This paper studies how reduced person-to-person travel costs affect firm productivity and supplier links in Japan, exploiting the March 2004 Kyushu Shinkansen opening. Using exhaustive firm-level buyer–seller linkages from TSR (≈950,000 firms), firm balance-sheet panels (2000–2008) and network snapshots in 2005 and 2010, the authors analyze firms and municipality-pair linkages across Japanese localities and industries. title: Salience, Myopia, and Complex Dynamic Incentives: Evidence from Medicare Part D
author: Christina M. Dalton, Gautam Gowrisankaran, Robert Town
context: Using 2008 administrative claims from Express Scripts for U.S. employer-sponsored Medicare Part D plans, the paper studies prescription purchase behavior of beneficiaries (age 65+) at the weekly enrollee level. title: Diversification through Trade
author: Francesco Caselli, Miklós Koren, Milan Lisicky, Silvana Tenreyro
context: This paper studies how declining trade costs since the early 1970s through 2007 affected GDP volatility across a multi-country sample (24 core countries plus a rest-of-world aggregate). The authors combine sector-level data (24 sectors), bilateral trade flows, and country-year observations with a calibrated multi-sector stochastic trade model that features country- and sector-specific productivity shocks and ex-ante labor allocation. Using the model and data, they back out trade costs and shocks and run counterfactuals to quantify trade’s causal impact on aggregate volatility.

context: This triplet examines how early-childhood Medicaid eligibility from the original U.S. Medicaid rollout (state implementation 1966–1970) affected adult disability transfer receipt for birth cohorts roughly 1936–1975. Outcomes are measured for native-born individuals aggregated by birth state, birth year, and race, using Census/ACS disability and program-participation data (primarily 2000–2007). Identification exploits the federal categorical-eligibility linkage to AFDC and cross-state differences in pre‑Medicaid AFDC rates to construct migration‑adjusted cumulative childhood exposure; effects on disability transfers are driven primarily by whites.

# Context
This triplet examines how early-childhood Medicaid eligibility from the original U.S. Medicaid rollout (state implementation 1966–1970) affected adult disability transfer receipt for birth cohorts roughly 1936–1975. Outcomes are measured for native-born individuals aggregated by birth state, birth year, and race, using Census/ACS disability and program-participation data (primarily 2000–2007). Identification exploits the federal categorical-eligibility linkage to AFDC and cross-state differences in pre‑Medicaid AFDC rates to construct migration‑adjusted cumulative childhood exposure; effects on disability transfers are driven primarily by whites.

title: Interfirm Relationships and Business Performance
author: Jing Cai, Adam Szeidl
context: A large-scale field experiment in Nanchang, China (2013–2015) studied owner-managed micro, small and medium enterprises established within the prior three years. From 2,800 interested firms researchers randomized 1,480 into treatment groups of ten managers who held monthly self-organized meetings for one year (Aug 2013–mid-2014) and 1,320 into a no-meetings control, with baseline (2013), midline (2014) and endline (2015) surveys. The program (run with the local CIIT) also randomized group composition, information shocks about financial products, and one-time cross-group meetings.

title: The Impacts of Neighborhoods on Intergenerational Mobility II: County-Level Estimates
author: Raj Chetty, Nathaniel Hendren
treatment: Exposure to a one SD better county
context: This estimate uses de-identified U.S. federal tax records for children born 1980–1986 (1996–2012 panel), measuring household incomes at age 26 (2006–2012). It reports county-level causal effects for children from low-income families (parents at the 25th percentile): one year of childhood exposure to a one standard-deviation better county raises adult household income by ~0.5% (≈10% from birth). Identification exploits families who move across U.S. counties/CZs, using exposure-time fixed-effect regressions (origin-by-destination controls); units are children/households.

title: How Are SNAP Benefits Spent? Evidence from a Retail Panel
author: Justine S. Hastings, Jesse M. Shapiro
context: Using transaction-level retailer panel data from February 2006–December 2012 together with Rhode Island and national SNAP administrative records, the paper analyzes how monthly SNAP EBT benefits affect household grocery and nonfood spending. The setting is a large U.S. grocery chain’s loyalty-card customers (≈486,570 households across several states) and administrative SNAP data for Rhode Island. The analyses exploit institutional features of SNAP: monthly electronic benefit disbursements, certification/recertification cycles (many spells divisible by six months), and legislated benefit increases (2008 Farm Bill and April 2009 ARRA).

title: The Returns to Nursing: Evidence from a Parental Leave Program
author: Benjamin U. Friedrich, Martin B. Hackmann
context: This paper studies Denmark's 1994 parental leave expansion using linked employer-employee, hospital patient, and death-register data for 1990–2000. It analyzes individual workers (nurses, nursing assistants, doctors), health providers (hospitals and nursing homes) and county-level markets, exploiting variation in eligibility by youngest-child age and county-sector exposure to a sudden 1994 reform that allowed up to one year leave for children ≤8 (job-protected, government-funded). The paper examines effects on nurse employment, hospital readmissions, and nursing-home mortality across counties and sectors.

title: Human Decisions and Machine Predictions
author: Jon Kleinberg, Himabindu Lakkaraju, Jure Leskovec, Jens Ludwig, Sendhil Mullainathan
context: This paper analyzes pre-trial bail decisions using administrative arrest records for 758,027 New York City defendants (Nov 2008–Nov 2013) and a national replication of 151,461 felony defendants (1990–2009) across 40 large counties. Units are arrested defendants; judges decide release versus detention under New York law (focus on failure-to-appear/flight risk). The design exploits quasi-random assignment of cases to judges within borough–courtroom–date cells, detailed rap-sheet/charge covariates, and observed outcomes only for released defendants, enabling policy counterfactuals via imputation and simulation.

title: The Historical State, Local Collective Action, and Economic Development in Vietnam
author: Melissa Dell, Nathaniel Lane, Pablo Querubin
context: This empirical study exploits the 1698 Dai Viet–Khmer boundary in southern Vietnam to estimate long-run effects of historical state institutions. It compares nearby villages/hamlets and households using historical maps (1878–1926), South Vietnamese-era hamlet and public-opinion surveys (1969–1973), income data (1970–72), and modern household consumption surveys (VHLSS 2002–2012). The setting contrasts centralized, village-based Dai Viet administration with patron-client Khmer governance, across episodes including French colonialism, the Vietnam War, and postwar communist rule.

author: Gideon Bornstein, Per Krusell, Sergio Rebelo

title: Monetary Policy and the Redistribution Channel
author: Adrien Auclert
context: This paper studies how monetary policy redistributes across heterogeneous households and thereby affects aggregate consumption, combining theory with micro evidence from household surveys: Italy’s SHIW (2010, self-reported MPCs), the U.S. PSID (1999–2013, semi-structural panel estimates of MPCs) and the U.S. Consumer Expenditure Survey (2001–2002, exploiting tax-rebate timing). title: How Merchant Towns Shaped Parliaments: From the Norman Conquest of England to the Great Reform Act
author: Charles Angelucci, Simone Meraglia, Nico Voigtländer
context: This paper studies 554 medieval English boroughs from the Norman Conquest (1066) through the Commercial Revolution and up to the Great Reform Act (1832), focusing on institutional changes mainly between 1066–1348 (Farm Grants) and long-run outcomes through 1642 (Civil War) and 1832. Units are towns/boroughs; key institutional features include royal vs mesne ownership, tax-farming, Farm Grants (municipal self-governance), parliamentary enfranchisement, and extra-ordinary taxation; analyses exploit Domesday Book wealth, trade geography (rivers, coast, Roman roads), and historical charters.

title: Subsidizing Health Insurance for Low-Income Adults: Evidence from Massachusetts
author: Amy Finkelstein, Nathaniel Hendren, Mark Shepard
context: This paper studies Massachusetts' subsidized insurance exchange "CommCare" from 2009–2013, focusing on fiscal year 2011. It uses individual-level administrative enrollment, claims, and reported income (% of FPL) for non-elderly adults (ages 19–64) eligible between 135–300% of the federal poverty level who lacked employer or Medicaid coverage. CommCare's subsidy schedule produced discrete premium jumps at 150%, 200%, and 250% FPL (and an individual mandate with penalties); these institutional discontinuities identify causal effects of enrollee premiums on take-up, selection, and insurer costs.

title: The Housing Boom and Bust: Model Meets Evidence
author: Greg Kaplan, Kurt Mitman, Giovanni L. Violante
context: This paper studies the U.S. housing boom and bust around the Great Recession (roughly 1997–2015), combining household-level lifecycle heterogeneous-agent data and aggregate time series. The unit of analysis is households in an overlapping-generations setting interacting with competitive rental, construction, and mortgage intermediation markets. It calibrates a structural incomplete-markets model with long-term defaultable mortgages, HELOCs, rental markets, and shocks to productivity, housing finance (LTV, PTI, origination costs) and beliefs about future housing demand, and evaluates counterfactuals including large-scale mortgage principal forgiveness.

title: Are There Too Many Farms in the World? Labor-Market Transaction Costs, Machine Capacities and Optimal Farm Size
author: Andrew D. Foster, Mark R. Rosenzweig
treatment: Economies of scale in machine capacity
context: The paper uses the India ICRISAT VLS panel (2009–2014, six rounds) covering 819 farm households in 18 villages across Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Karnataka, Maharashtra and Madhya Pradesh. Units of observation are plots and farm households with high-frequency (operation-level) input, hours and wage data, monthly village price schedules and machine-use records (notably sprayers). context: The paper studies U.S. private nonfarm businesses from 1983–2013, using plant-level microdata (Longitudinal Business Database) and manufacturing subsamples to quantify measurement bias ('missing growth') from statistical imputation when products exit (creative destruction).
