title: Inferring Inequality with Home Production
author: Job Boerma, Loukas Karabarbounis
context: This paper analyzes U.S. households (married/cohabiting heads aged 25–65) using CEX consumption data (1995–2016), ATUS time-use data (2003–2017) and CPS tax information to infer how home production affects welfare inequality. The setting is a U.S. market and non-tradeable home sector with incomplete asset markets, uninsurable permanent wage heterogeneity, and a parametric progressive tax schedule. The authors structurally map cross-sectional consumption, market hours, wages, and imputed home hours into a heterogeneous-agent general-equilibrium model to quantify inequality and optimal tax progressivity.

title: Structural Interpretation of Vector Autoregressions with Incomplete Identification: Revisiting the Role of Oil Supply and Demand Shocks
author: Christiane J.S. Baumeister, James D. Hamilton
context: The paper analyzes monthly global oil-market data (world crude production, OECD+6 industrial production, oil prices and estimated OECD inventories) spanning the late 1950s through 2016, with particular attention to pre-1975 and 1975–2016 samples. title: Market Failure in Kidney Exchange

context: Analyzes the U.S. kidney exchange market using administrative transplant records (OPTN) and registry data from the National Kidney Registry (NKR), covering roughly 2008–2014 (NKR registrations April 2012–Dec 2014). title: From Population Growth to Firm Demographics: Implications for Concentration, Entrepreneurship and the Labor Share
author: Hugo Hopenhayn, Julian Neira, Rish Singhania
treatment: Pre-1978 rise in labor force growth
outcome: Magnitude of subsequent entry rate decline
context: The paper studies U.S. private-sector firms over the long run (feeding civilian labor-force growth from the 1940s through 2014 and firm-level data 1977–2014) to link changes in population/labor-force growth—largely driven by the baby boom—to firm entry, firm-age composition, employment concentration, and the aggregate labor share. title: The Origins of Firm Heterogeneity: A Production Network Approach
author: Andrew B. Bernard, Emmanuel Dhyne, Glenn Magerman, Kalina Manova, Andreas Moxnes
context: This paper analyzes the origins of firm size heterogeneity using the universe of domestic firm-to-firm transactions in Belgium, focusing on the 2014 cross-section with robustness checks over 2002–2014. The unit of observation is firms and directed seller–buyer transactions, linked to firm balance sheets, VAT records and industry (NACE) codes; the B2B dataset records essentially all domestic inter-firm sales above €250. The analysis conditions on the observed equilibrium production network and combines high-dimensional two-way fixed-effects estimation with a structural mapping and general-equilibrium counterfactuals.

title: Employment Structure and the Rise of the Modern Tax System
author: Anders Jensen
context: The paper combines recent cross-country household surveys (100 countries) and long-run U.S. microdata (1870–2010) with a causal analysis of U.S. states in the 1950s–1960s. The main causal test exploits variation in the timing of state Industrial Development Bonds (IDB) implementation—specifically the lag between legislative vote-in and state supreme-court upholding—to estimate effects on individual employment structure, the personal income tax exemption threshold, and state income tax revenue. Units are individuals/households for distributional profiles and U.S. states for the policy-event analysis; key institutions include revenue bonds and IRS information-exchange agreements.

author: Brigham R. Frandsen, Lars J. Lefgren, Emily C. Leslie

title: Using Disasters to Estimate the Impact of Uncertainty
author: Scott R. Baker, Nicholas Bloom, Stephen J. Terry
context: This paper analyzes quarterly country-level data for 59 countries from 1970Q1 to 2020Q1, using country-quarter observations of GDP growth, national stock-market returns and volatility. The authors exploit exogenous shocks — natural disasters, terrorist attacks, coups and revolutions — weighted by short-run jumps in U.S. newspaper coverage to instrument first- and second-moment (level and uncertainty) shocks in asset returns. The setting spans advanced and emerging economies, linking financial-market moments to short-run macro outcomes while accounting for spatial spillovers, alternative uncertainty proxies, and model-based simulations.

title: Earnings Inequality and the Minimum Wage: Evidence from Brazil

title: Market Segmentation and Competition in Health Insurance
author: Michael J. Dickstein, Kate Ho, Nathaniel D. Mark
treatment: Pooling small group and individual markets
outcome: Extent of adverse selection in individual market
context: This paper empirically analyzes U.S. health‑insurance market segmentation using Oregon all‑payer claims and plan files (2014–2016), comparing small‑group (employer) and individual marketplace enrollment and premiums for households. Units are households and plans; authors exploit “forced switchers” who lose employer coverage, insurer premium and MLR data, and ACA institutional features (guaranteed issue, metal tiers, risk adjustment, risk corridors, reinsurance). They structurally estimate demand and insurer pricing to simulate counterfactual pooling (e.g., ICHRA employer shifts) and validate results using multi‑state premium/MLR data.

title: Local Economic and Political Effects of Trade Deals: Evidence from NAFTA

context: This paper studies local economic and political effects of NAFTA’s tariff reductions around its 1993–1994 passage, using U.S. county and commuting-zone annual data from the mid-1980s through the early 2000s and individual survey/panel data (ANES repeated cross-sections and 1992–1994 panel, PSID). context: The paper studies the effect of the American Inventors Protection Act (AIPA) of 1999—which required U.S. patent applications filed on or after Nov 29, 2000 to be published 18 months after filing—on innovation and knowledge diffusion. title: Indirect Effects of Access to Finance

title: Estimation of a Life-Cycle Model with Human Capital, Labor Supply and Retirement
author: Xiaodong Fan, Ananth Seshadri, Christopher R. Taber
context: This paper uses U.S. microdata (SIPP panels 1984–2008 and CPS panels 1979–2018) to estimate a structural life-cycle model of consumption, human-capital investment, labor supply and Social Security claiming. Focusing on male high-school graduates (individual-level units, estimation from ages ~22 up to 80), it models U.S. Social Security rules (claiming from age 62, normal retirement 65, using 2004 rules) and simulates counterfactual benefit and tax changes. Estimation employs indirect inference to match life-cycle employment and measured-wage profiles; extensions include health shocks and part-time work.

title: Increasing the Demand for Workers with a Criminal Record

context: This paper uses a randomized field experiment conducted March–April 2020 on a large U.S. nationwide staffing platform to measure employer demand for workers with criminal records. context: This paper studies the 2013 French dividend payroll-tax reform that tripled the tax rate on dividends to owner-managers of SARL firms (from 15.5% to 46%). It uses administrative tax and accounting panel data covering the universe of private firms over 2008–2017. The unit of analysis is closely-held firms/owner-managers (SARL treated, SAS controls), exploiting legal-status variation and staggered fiscal-year treatment timing to estimate effects on payouts, retained earnings, capital and labor accumulation, revenues, and exit.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions

# Context
This paper studies the 2013 French dividend payroll-tax reform that tripled the tax rate on dividends to owner-managers of SARL firms (from 15.5% to 46%). It uses administrative tax and accounting panel data covering the universe of private firms over 2008–2017. The unit of analysis is closely-held firms/owner-managers (SARL treated, SAS controls), exploiting legal-status variation and staggered fiscal-year treatment timing to estimate effects on payouts, retained earnings, capital and labor accumulation, revenues, and exit.

title: Wealth of Two Nations: The U.S. Racial Wealth Gap, 1860-2020
author: Ellora Derenoncourt, Chi Hyun Kim, Moritz Kuhn, Moritz Schularick
context: This paper constructs a continuous national series of white-to-Black per-capita wealth ratios in the United States from 1860 to 2020, using historical complete-count censuses, southern state tax records, Monroe Work’s Negro Year Book, and the Survey of Consumer Finances. The unit of analysis is racial groups’ per-capita (and household-level) wealth nationally. The analysis situates wealth dynamics in institutional contexts—slavery, Emancipation, Reconstruction, Jim Crow, New Deal, the Civil Rights era, and post-1980 asset-price booms—and examines how initial conditions, income growth, savings behavior, and capital gains shaped long-run convergence and divergence.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Pricing Power in Advertising Markets: Theory and Evidence
author: Matthew Gentzkow, Jesse M. Shapiro, Frank Yang, Ali Yurukoglu
context: The paper studies US advertising markets, primarily focusing on the linear television market in 2014–2019 with cross-sectional analyses centered on 2015. Units include television outlets (network×daypart), network owners, advertisers, and individual viewers from the 2015 GfK MRI survey; data sources include Nielsen Ad Intel and S&P/SNL ownership records. The authors also analyze Facebook ad auction data from targeted ad experiments. The economic setting is competitive two-sided ad markets with multi-homing viewers and diminishing returns to impressions; counterfactuals consider mergers and Netflix carrying ads.

title: The Effect of Macroeconomic Uncertainty on Firm Decisions
author: Saten Kumar, Yuriy Gorodnichenko, Olivier Coibion
context: Using two survey waves in New Zealand (first wave June–Oct 2021, follow-up Nov 2021–Feb 2022), the authors survey ~4,000 firms (about 2,000 reinterviewed) employing ≥6 workers. They randomized information treatments that provided professional forecasters' mean GDP forecasts and/or the spread between optimistic and pessimistic forecasts to exogenously shift firms' macroeconomic first- and second-moment beliefs during the pandemic period. Outcomes include firms' planned and realized prices, employment, investment, sales, advertising, and decisions to adopt technologies or open facilities.

title: Superiority-Seeking and the Preference for Exclusion
author: Alex Imas, Kristóf Madarász
context: This paper combines theoretical modeling with randomized laboratory and online experiments to test whether individuals value goods more when others are barred from obtaining them. Experiments (university lab sessions and Prolific online samples) elicited individual willingness-to-pay and first-price auction bids for unique goods (custom T-shirts, an art print) under Baseline, Random Exclusion, and Non‑Random Exclusion treatments, with groups of M=4,6,8 subjects. Core institutional features include BDM purchasing and sealed-bid auctions, transparent random exclusion, and incentivized payments and delivery.

title: Investing in Infants: The Lasting Effects of Cash Transfers to New Families
author: Andrew C. Barr, Jonathan Eggleston, Alexander A. Smith
context: This paper studies U.S. children born around January 1 in cohorts from the 1980s and 1990s (recentered birth years 1981–82, 1985–86, 1991–92), leveraging the federal tax code’s January 1 cutoff for dependent status that creates large discontinuities in EITC and dependent-exemption refunds in the child’s first year. title: Eviction and Poverty in American Cities
author: Robert Collinson, John Eric Humphries, Nicholas S. Mader, Davin K. Reed, Daniel I. Tannenbaum, Winnie van Dijk
context: This paper studies individual tenants named in housing court eviction cases in Cook County (including Chicago) and New York City using near-universe court records (Cook County 2000–2016; NYC 2007–2016) linked to administrative data (UI earnings, HMIS shelter records, Experian credit reports, and hospital visits). Focusing on case-individuals, the authors leverage random assignment of cases to judges in these urban housing courts to estimate causal effects of court-ordered eviction on homelessness, earnings, employment, health, and financial outcomes while accounting for pre-filing dynamics.

title: New Frontiers: The Origins and Content of New Work, 1940–2018
author: David Autor, Caroline Chin, Anna M. Salomons, Bryan Seegmiller
context: Analyzes the United States, 1940–2018, linking decadal Census/ACS microdata on occupations and industry write-ins to a constructed database of new job micro‑titles and to the full text of U.S. utility patents. Units of observation are occupations and occupation×industry cells (decadal panels); key institutional features are the Census Alphabetical Index (CAI) and the Dictionary of Occupational Titles (DOT) used to map patents (via word‑embeddings) into augmentation vs. automation exposure. The paper leverages exogenous demand shocks (China import exposure, demographic shifts) and patent‑based instruments (breakthrough patents lagged two decades) to identify causal effects.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions; other time-series regressions

title: The Gift of a Lifetime: The Hospital, Modern Medicine, and Mortality
author: Alex Hollingsworth, Krzysztof Karbownik, Melissa A. Thomasson, Anthony Wray
context: This paper studies the causal impact of The Duke Endowment’s hospital modernization program (1927–1942) on hospital capacity, physician quality, infant mortality (birth cohorts 1922–1942) and long-run mortality (1932–1941 cohorts observed at ages 56–64) in North Carolina counties. context: Analyzes U.S. labor markets from the 1950s through the 1970s with emphasis on the 1960s, leveraging the passage and implementation of the 1963 Equal Pay Act and 1964 Civil Rights Act. title: The (Lack of) Anticipatory Effects of the Social Safety Net on Human Capital Investment
author: Manasi Deshpande, Rebecca Dizon-Ross
context: This paper reports a nationally drawn randomized controlled trial (Oct 2021–Jan 2022, U.S., with oversamples in Michigan, Wisconsin, and Massachusetts) of about 6,000 parents of 14–17-year-old children receiving Supplemental Security Income (SSI). Using SSA administrative data to predict each child’s probability of removal at the age-18 redetermination, the experiment randomized a video giving that prediction and measured parents’ belief updates and take-up of offered human-capital resources (tutoring, job training, math lessons). The institutional setting is the U.S. SSI program, where child and adult eligibility differ and many youth lose benefits at 18.

title: The Impact of Public School Choice: Evidence from Los Angeles' Zones of Choice
author: Christopher Campos, Caitlin Kearns
context: This paper studies Los Angeles Unified School District’s Zones of Choice (ZOC) reform—implemented starting around 2012–2013—using administrative data from roughly 2008–2019. It evaluates effects on high-school students (chiefly 11th graders and graduating cohorts) and market-level school outcomes across ZOC versus non-ZOC neighborhoods in Los Angeles. ZOC combined catchment areas, expanded within-district choice with centralized rank-ordered (immediate-acceptance) assignment and lotteries for oversubscription, thereby changing competitive incentives among attendance-zone schools.

This paper studies Los Angeles Unified School District’s Zones of Choice (ZOC) reform—implemented starting around 2012–2013—using administrative data from roughly 2008–2019. It evaluates effects on high-school students (chiefly 11th graders and graduating cohorts) and market-level school outcomes across ZOC versus non-ZOC neighborhoods in Los Angeles. title: Retirement Consumption and Pension Design
author: Jonas Kolsrud, Camille Landais, Daniel Reck, Johannes Spinnewijn
context: Using linked Swedish administrative registries and registry-based household consumption measures for cohorts born 1938–1943 (consumption observed circa 2000–2007), the paper studies individuals/households retiring between roughly ages 55–70. The institutional setting is Sweden’s public pension system (ATP→NDC transition), occupational pensions and social insurance (UI/DI), where benefits depend on retirement age, career length and earnings. The analysis exploits variation in actual retirement timing and rich panel covariates to relate consumption levels and dynamics around retirement to pension design.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Organized Crime and Economic Growth: Evidence from Municipalities Infiltrated by the Mafia
author: Alessandra Fenizia, Raffaele Saggio
context: This empirical study evaluates long-run effects of city-council dismissals (CCDs) for alleged Mafia infiltration in Italy, analyzing 245 CCD events from 1991–2016 across municipalities in ten regions. It uses administrative employer–employee social security data (1983–2017), real-estate, public-procurement, politician, and municipal finance records to measure impacts on firms, employment, wages, and real-estate. Institutional context: the central government investigates alleged Mafia ties and appoints commissioners to run dismissed municipalities for about two years before new elections, creating plausibly exogenous variation for causal analysis.

title: The Long-Run Effects of America's Largest Residential Racial Desegregation Program: Gautreaux
author: Eric Chyn, Robert Collinson, Danielle H. Sandler
outcome: Likelihood of marrying a white spouse
context: This paper analyzes long-run causal effects of the Gautreaux Assisted Housing Program (program operated 1976–1998; main sample 1982–1994) in the Chicago metropolitan area, linking historical placement records to administrative data through 2019/2020.
